response:
[start of motion plan]
The task is to give the pained man a thorough neck massage while grasping the neck.

Mapping World Motion to Wrist Motion:
The provided workspace image confirms the robot end-effector is grasping the side of the man's neck firmly near the base of the head. The environment is an indoor workspace with a wooden table, a seated man leaning forward, and the robot arm positioned adjacent to the man. The neck is soft tissue with some stiffness, and the objective is to massage by moving and applying forces on the neck skin and musculature. The grasp point is roughly cylindrical and curved, requiring moderate grip force without causing discomfort.

The labeled wrist axes correspond to the world as such: The red wrist X-axis points roughly horizontally forward to the man's face and neck side (rightward and forward relative to the camera). The green wrist Y-axis points roughly downward and slightly inward toward the man's shoulder (downward and slightly inward in the world). The blue wrist Z-axis points roughly upward along the man's head vertical axis (upward in the world corresponds mainly to wrist Z-axis positive direction).

The blue axis represents wrist Z-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to vertical motion upwards along the man's neck axis. Positive wrist Z-axis motion moves the contact up the neck vertically, negative moves downward towards the shoulder. For the massage, gentle sliding and lifting motions are required up and down to stimulate the neck muscles.

Based on knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist Z-axis, the object must move moderately positive and negative (up and down sliding) to perform the massage strokes.

The red axis represents wrist X-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to forward (toward the man's face) and backward motion along the side of the neck. Positive wrist X-axis motion moves forward along the neck's longitudinal axis, while negative moves away from the face towards the back of the head.

Based on knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist X-axis, small oscillatory forward and backward movements are needed to massage and knead the neck muscles.

The green axis represents wrist Y-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to inward/outward lateral squeezing and pressing onto the neck tissues (downward relative to camera and slightly toward the man's body). Positive wrist Y-axis motion is slightly downward and inward, negative upward and outward.

Based on knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist Y-axis, small pressing and lifting motions (both positive and negative directions) are needed to knead and manipulate the neck muscles gently.

To accomplish the task in the wrist frame, the object must be moved with smooth oscillatory and sliding motions along the X and Z axes (forward/backward and up/down along the neck) combined with gentle in/out pressing motions along the Y axis for kneading. These are low amplitude continuous motions.

Wrist Force/Torque Motion Estimation:
Linear X-axis: To complete the task, the robot must exert alternating positive and negative force along the X-axis with magnitude about 8 N on the neck to simulate rubbing and kneading pressure without discomfort.

Linear Y-axis: To complete the task, the robot must exert alternating positive and negative force along the Y-axis with magnitude about 10 N on the neck to apply appropriate squeezing pressure for massage.

Linear Z-axis: To complete the task, the robot must exert alternating positive and negative force along the Z-axis with magnitude about 6 N aligned with sliding motions to lift and slide along the neck muscles.

Angular X-axis: To complete the task, the robot must exert slight clockwise and counterclockwise torque about the X-axis with magnitude around 0.5 N-m to twist and rotate the contact lightly for kneading motions.

Angular Y-axis: To complete the task, the robot must exert slight clockwise and counterclockwise torque about the Y-axis with magnitude around 0.3 N-m to achieve lateral rolling massage motions on the curved neck surface.

Angular Z-axis: To complete the task, the robot must exert slight clockwise and counterclockwise torque about the Z-axis with magnitude around 0.2 N-m for fine rotational adjustments of wrist orientation to maintain contact.

Grasping force: The hand neck contact must maintain firm but comfortable grasping to avoid slippage and apply massage force. Assuming dry skin with moderate friction (~0.5), lightweight head mass supported by the seated posture, a grasping force range of 15 to 25 N is reasonable to ensure stable yet comfortable grasp.

Python Code with Final Motion Plan:
```python
# succinct text description of the explicit estimated physical properties of the object, including mass, material, friction coefficients, etc.
property_description = "Human neck tissue, soft skin and muscle, curved cylindrical geometry, estimated 4 kg head mass supported, skin friction coefficient ~0.5."

# succinct text description of the motion plan along the wrist axes
wrist_motion_description = "Smooth oscillatory sliding motions along wrist X (forward/backward) and Z (up/down) axes combined with gentle pressing oscillations along wrist Y (inward/outward), plus small torques about all axes for kneading and orientation adjustments."

# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of motion across the wrist axes [x, y ,z].
wrist_motion_vector = [0.015, 0.010, 0.020]  # meters amplitude representing continuous small massage strokes

# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of the forces and torques along the wrist's [x, y, z, rx, ry, rz] axes
wrist_wrench = [8.0, 10.0, 6.0, 0.5, 0.3, 0.2]  # Newtons linear force and Newton-meters torques

# the grasping force, which must be positive
grasp_force = 20.0  # Newtons, stable but comfortable grasp

# the task duration, which must be positive
duration = 180.0  # seconds, approximately 3 minutes for thorough massage
```

[end of motion plan]
message:
Given the user instruction and an image of the robot workspace, generate a structured physical plan for a robot end-effector interacting with the environment.
The task is to give the pained man a thorough neck massage while grasping the neck.

The robot is controlled using position and torque-based control, with access to contact feedback and 6D motion capabilities. 
Motions can include grasping, lifting, pushing, tapping, sliding, rotating, or any interaction with objects or surfaces.
Motion can resolve across multiple axes, so be careful to consider all axes of motion to accomplish the task.

Reason about the provided and implicit information in the images and task description to generate a structured plan for the robot's motion. Think about:
- Object geometry and contact points (from the image)
- Force/torque sensing at the wrist
- Prior knowledge of object material types and mass estimates
- Environmental knowledge (table, gravity, hinge resistance, etc.)

The robot workspace view labeled with the axes of motion relative to the wrist of the robot, placed at the point of grasping. The wrist of the robot may be oriented differently from the canonical world-axes, so this workspace view may help understand the wrist-relative motion to accomplish the task in the world.
World Motion Reference: As ground truth reference for world motion relative to the robot, the workspace camera view roughly corresponds to canonical motion in the world. 
Upward motion in the world corresponds to motion up workspace camera view image, 
Right-ward motion in the world corresponds to motion to the right of the workspace camera view image, 
And forward motion in the world corresponds to motion into the workspace camera view image.
The wrist frame axes will roughly correspond to these directions, but will be more aligned with the gripper-object relative motion.

Use physical reasoning to complete the following plan in a structured format. Carefully map the required motion in the world to the required motion, forces, and torques at the wrist.

Rules:
1. Replace all {DESCRIPTION: ...}, {PNUM}, {NUM}, and {CHOICE: ...} entries with specific values or statements. For example, {PNUM} should be replaced with a number like 0.5. This is very important for downstream parsing!!
2. Use best physical reasoning based on known robot/environmental capabilities. Remember that the robot may have to exert forces in additional axes compared to the motion direction axes in order to maintain contacts between the object, robot, and environment.
3. Always include motion for all axes of motion, even if it's "No motion required."
4. Keep the explanation concise but physically grounded. Prioritize interpretability and reproducibility.
5. Use common sense where exact properties are ambiguous, and explain assumptions.
6. Do not include any sections outside the start/end blocks or add non-specified bullet points.
7. Make sure to provide the final python code for each requested force in a code block. Remember to fully replace the placeholder text with the actual values!
8. Do not abbreviate the prompt when generating the response. Fully reproduce the template, but filled in with your reasoning.
9. Make sure to refer to the provided correspondence in the direction guide between motion in the world frame and positive/negative motion in the respective axes.
